newsitem.title: USA: PG&E Calif. pumped storage hydropower plant shut.
newsitem.headline: PG&E Calif. pumped storage hydropower plant shut.

text.p: Pacific Gas and Electric Co's 1,100 megawatt (MW) Helms pumped storage hydroelectric project on the Kings River east of Fresno, Calif., will be off-line for one or two weeks, company spokesman Jeff Lewis said Monday.
The unit was shut Saturday morning because of an unidentified equipment problem, he said.
The Helms unit operates as a "peaking" plant, producing power during daytime hours when power demand hits a daily peak.
During off-peak hours at night the plant uses power to move water uphill, where is it released to flow downhill through power turbines during the day.
Normally, power produced at the utility's Diablo Canyon nuclear plant is routed to Helms at night for the storage pumping, Lewis explained.
As a result of the recent outage, output from Diablo Canyon was partially curtailed over the past weekend.
But PG&E does not expect to continue reducing power from the nuclear plant during off-peak hours, the spokesman said.
"We are looking at other ways to sell or otherwise take care of" the excess off-peak power from Diablo Canyon, Lewis added.
